Posts.Content: missz wrote: Hi....new here. I went in for my first ever baseline mammogram today. After they looked at the films the doctor did an ultrasound as he thought I might have a cyst. I saw it- rough edges, not a solid looking mass- he said it didn't look like a cyst but aspirated it to be sure. No fluid- not a cyst. So he did a needle biopsy. This is all out of the blue to me. My maternal grandma had breast cancer but I was told, as long as it's not mom or sister, mammograms usually start at 40 (I am 37). I was never told nor had I read about the link to colon cancer- found that out today. My mom had Stage 4 colon cancer which almost killed her. I'm terrified. I won't hear anything for two days. My boyfriend lives across the country and I can't find him. My mom's across the country too and I don't want to scare her. My friends are being great but I'm just losing it. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: missz wrote: I have a mass in my left breast which has been core needle biopsied with thank God B9 results- however I've had two doctors who read the path report and saw the films say that, while it says benign, it does not say what the mass is, plus the ultrasound and mammos make it look suspicious (RADS 4), so the biopsy may have missed the mass/may be incomplete and so it should come out entirely. Then I had surgical consult #3 today and HE said I could 50% do that, 50% have it needle biopsied again or possibly vacuum biopsied. At this point my head is spinning and I don't know what to do. Is it common for biopsies to completely miss? My ultrasound shows the needle going right through the mass. I just want this over with and the thought of biopsy after biopsy is really stressful- but so is surgery. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: missz wrote: I had an excisional biopsy of a 1 cm mass in May. Not cancer but both ALH and ADH present. Recommended was a screening schedule of alternating mammos and MRIs every six months. My insurance company is refusing to cover the MRI. I am trying to find every avenue of what it means to have both- seems to definitely elevate risk. Any advice? My family history isn't too scary- but mom with colon cancer at 55 and grandmom with BC at 70. Insurance will cover me if I test positive for BRCA - but I truly believe that would be enormous trouble with insurance later. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 21, 2007 05:26PM missz wrote: I have an atypical hyperplasia lump at age 37, or rather, I had one until Thursday when I removed it. Mine is ALH not ADH. I agree that you need a good relationship with a breast specialist whom you trust. He or she will be able to advise you on the fibroadenoma, risk factors, etc., and put you on a screening program. Good luck!!
